raw_text:
Housewives lift Channel 4 ratings
 
 The debut of US television hit Desperate Housewives has helped lift Channel 4's January audience share by 12% compared to last year.
 
 Other successes such as Celebrity Big Brother and The Simpsons have enabled the broadcaster to surpass BBC Two for the first month since last July. BBC Two's share of the audience fell from 11.2% to 9.6% last month in comparison with January 2004. Celebrity Big Brother attracted fewer viewers than its 2002 series.
 
 Comedy drama Desperate Housewives managed to pull in five million viewers at one point during its run to date, attracting a quarter of the television audience. The two main television channels, BBC1 and ITV1, have both seen their monthly audience share decline in a year on year comparison for January, while Five's proportion remained the same at a slender 6.3%. Digital multi-channel TV is continuing to be the strongest area of growth, with the BBC reporting Freeview box ownership of five million, including one million sales in the last portion of 2004. Its share of the audience soared by 20% in January 2005 compared with last year, and currently stands at an average of 28.6%.
llama3.2:1b: Housewives lift Channel 4 ratings; surpass BBC Two.
Other shows like Celebrity Big Brother and The Simpsons also boost channel's audience share.
Five sees slight decline in monthly audience share.
Digital TV grows strongest area of growth, with Freeview reaching 28.6% average audience share.
llama3.2:3b: Channel 4's January audience share rose 12% due to successes like Desperate Housewives and Celebrity Big Brother, surpassing BBC Two.
Digital multi-channel TV growth accelerated, with Freeview box ownership increasing to 5 million and the BBC's digital share soaring by 20%.
gemma2:2b: Channel 4's January viewership increased 12% due to the success of shows like "Desperate Housewives" and "Celebrity Big Brother".
BBC Two lost audience share (9.6%) to Channel 4's growth, with a decline in overall television audience on both BBC1 and ITV1, while Five remained stable at 6.3%.
Digital multi-channel TV saw significant growth, particularly Freeview boxes which experienced a 20% increase in viewership.

The audience share rose by 12%, while both BBC1/ITV1 saw decreases and ITV5 remained stable at 6.3%.
Digital TV is experiencing strong growth with a freeview box ownership of five million.
qwen2.5:3b: The debut of US show Desperate Housewives boosted Channel 4's January audience share by 12%, surpassing BBC Two for the first month since July.
Other shows like Celebrity Big Brother and The Simpsons also contributed to this increase.
In contrast, BBC Two’s share fell from 11.2% to 9.6%.
Desperate Housewives attracted five million viewers at its peak, reaching a quarter of all TV audiences.
While both BBC1 and ITV1 saw declines in their audience shares compared to January 2004, Channel 5's share remained steady at 6.3%.

Digital multi-channel TV showed strong growth with Freeview box ownership increasing by 20% year-on-year to five million, including one million sales in the last quarter of 2004, and currently standing at an average audience share of 28.6%.

The two main television channels, BBC1 and ITV1, have both seen their monthly audience share decline in a year on year comparison for January, while Digital multi-channel TV is continuing to be the strongest area of growth.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The rise in ratings for Channel 4 is attributed to the success of Desperate Housewives, which helped lift their audience share by 12% compared to last year.
Other shows like Celebrity Big Brother and The Simpsons contributed to Channel 4 surpassing BBC Two for the first time since July 2003, with a decline in BBC Two's audience share from 11.2% to 9.6%.
Celebrity Big Brother had fewer viewers than its 2002 counterpart.

Desperate Housewives attracted five million viewers, a quarter of the TV audience, while BBC1 and ITV1 saw shares declining each year, with freeview box ownership expanding to 5 million, up from 3.4 million in 2004.
Summary: The show Desperate Housewives boosted Channel 4's ratings by 12%, while other shows like Celebrity Big Brother and The Simpsons helped surpass BBC Two.
BBC Two saw a drop in audience share, and freeview box ownership improved.
tinyllama:1.1b: Despite facing competition from BBC Two and Five's digital channels, Channel 4 achieved a rise in audience share in January 2005 thanks to the success of its US series "Desperate Housewives," which attracted nearly five million viewers at one point during its run.

Despite losing viewers compared with the same period last year, Five saw its proportion remain unchanged at 6.3%, while Digital multi-channel TV was seeing growth, with the BBC's share of the audience surging by 20% in January 2005.
The rise in audience share is attributed to Desperate Housewives' popularity and Channel 4's focus on digital channels.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The debut of US television hit Desperate Housewives has helped Channel 4's January audience-share by 12%, surpassing BBC Two's previous record of 11.2% in comparison to last July.

This improvement is attributed to a combination of factors including the popularity of Celebrity Big Brother and The Simpsons, which have enabled Channel 4 to outperform BBC Two for the first month since last July.

Although comedic drama Desperate Housewives managed to attract five million viewers during its run to date, it was not enough to surpass the audience of its 2002 series, with a quarter of ITV1's total audience share also declining in comparison for January.

Meanwhile, Five's performance has remained steady at around 6.3% for the month, while digital multi-channel TV is continuing to be the strongest area of growth among broadcast channels, with BBC experiencing a slump of 20% in January compared to last year.
phi:2.7b: The debut of Desperate Housewives on Channel 4 has boosted its ratings, helping it surpass BBC Two for the first time since July 2004.
Other successful shows like Celebrity Big Brother and The Simpsons have also contributed to this success.
In January 2005, Channel 4's audience share increased by 12% compared to the previous year, while BBC2's share fell from 11.2% to 9.6%.
Despite a decline in monthly audience shares for ITV1 and Five, digital multi-channel TV continued its strong growth with an average of 28.6% viewership.
The BBC reported five million Freeview box owners in January 2005, representing a 20% increase compared to the previous year.
